Your Majesty, may I trouble you a moment? Forgive me, but I must confess—word nears me on the wings of the wind that you have at last mastered Hamlet’s little iron pigeon. What a wonder! The very marvel of the court, they say. Did it not peck at Lord Polonius’ boots just last night? I warrant, you keep these amusements for yourself and young prince alone. Is there a meaning to it all—do you meet in secret, plotting flight across the sea?

Lady Lily, you do entertain the court’s fancies with a master’s tongue. An iron pigeon? These are illusions bred of idle heads and late-night drink. Young Hamlet is much given to toys and schoolboy jests, but I, a man encumbered with the yoke of Denmark, have neither hour nor heart for such diversions. No bird of metal nor winged mischief shall take me from my kingly cares. If Polonius hath met with any pigeon—iron or else—I shall have words with him on the matter. Now pry not further, or you’ll be chasing peacocks in the moonlight.

Oh, Your Grace! Is my tongue too swift? Blame not a simple soul curious for mysteries. The contraption is the least: what truly sets the candles flickering are tales that you, sweet Claudius, teach Hamlet old star-charts by the window—saying that Sirius pours wisdom into men’s ears, or that Jupiter scolds the unkind king. And then—ah, you must forgive the kitchen boys, for they swore upon the saints that they saw Your Highness passing to the prince a disc of bread, crowned with scarlet fruit and green herb, which Hamlet called “pizza.” Tell me—do you dabble in astrology, or bake forbidden pies at midnight, my Liege?

Lady Lily, thou art light-tongued beyond measure, and near impertinent. If every servant’s fancy were given voice, this court would ring with talk of dragons, mermaids, and men who fly upon bread! Hamlet is a scholar: he fills his mind with all manner of foreign tongue and nonsense—star-charts, pizza, whatever madness infects the modern youth. As for me, am I a baker, that you accuse me? A king with flour on his brow, or tomatoes beneath his ring! Mind yourself, lest rumor twine itself about your brow and choke true sense from you. I do not brook such mockery, however slyly it’s dressed.

Dear King, how sharp your words, though droll enough to slice a loaf! Would you wound one for seeking to know? I wonder, Majesty, what else Elsinore’s stones might tell if they had ears—perhaps of spectral birds returned from the grave, piping secrets from the other world, or of queens who taste of hidden recipes by lamplight. Some say the iron pigeon is the work of a conjurer Hamlet befriended at university—a man with clockwork in his veins, who could make miniature goats dance a minuet. Is it not odd? Yesterday Hamlet told Laertes the pigeon sings when fed a crystal pebble. Such tricks! But if only Hamlet, Laertes, and my king keep such council, what should the rest of us think? Are we unworthy of the future?

Enough, Lily! Your tongue wags on as foolishly persistent as a jester’s bell. You trade in shadows and sculpt mischief from air. No iron pigeon, no crystal pebble, no alchemical goat shall dictate the business or destiny of Denmark. I have said plain: Hamlet toys with nonsense, and I am too burdened with the weight of the crown to nurse childish amusements or parley with university warlocks. Would you paint me a fool before God and men? Take heed—this is no jesting matter. If you seek truth, look not to phantoms or baseless tales. And let that be the end.

You are angered, Sire. Pray, forgive me. I only thought to brighten your path—surely, a man beset by Denmark’s cares might cherish oddity now and again. A pigeon, a recipe, a moment’s release from sorrow! If I have pressed too tightly, let me loosen my grip. But rumor flies faster sometimes than even an iron bird, and I would not see you entangled by others’ fancies. Perhaps you’d like to join me, then, in a slice of honesty—a plain loaf and plain questions, no strange fruits or mechanical beasts?

I have no need of mystical bread, nor the company of those who feign innocence to pepper their words with accusation. I see through your cleverness, Lily—your questions are arrows, not crumbs. Mind where you aim. The court tolerates some wit, but not all barbed amusements. Go—seek company more suited to your appetite. Let me be about kingly business, as is proper for one of my station.

If it must be, then I am gone, my gracious Lord. Perhaps I will find amusement with Marcellus—he, at least, will wager a silver coin that pigeons eat more pebbles than kings. Good evening, Your Grace. And may you never be attacked by iron beaks.
Leave me, and take your riddles with you. \ The rest is silence.

My lord, your brow is furrowed—a storm behind those royal eyes. Might it be the strain of arranging the next masquerade ball with the Swedish Prince? I've heard no such commotion since you and Yorick were plotting entertainments at court. Surely, with friends so jovial and close to your heart, the burdens of kingship cannot weigh so heavily? \ But, I do wonder, did Yorick ever teach you those intricate juggling tricks I hear you two practiced in the west tower? Or is it true that, more recently, you have consulted physicists from Florence on the movement of the celestial orbs, hoping to bring a great mechanical lion to Elsinore’s feasts?

Lily, thou hast a lively tongue and a mind prone to far flights. Yorick, whose skull now rests with the worms, was my brother’s jester—never have I been one for tumbling, nor did I stoop to juggle with that merry soul. And as for Princes of Sweden and machines with heart of steel, these are strange notions, nursed perhaps by wine or overfondness for fable. Dost thou mock thy king, or do the shadows breed jest in thee tonight?

I would ne’er dare mock a king! Though I’ve heard, in whispers through the folds of drapery—that you once played chess all through the longest night with Queen Gertrude and the Spanish lagoon-dancers, wagering pearls upon the turn of each piece. \ Yet, sweet my lord, I am curious—have you ever composed love sonnets in secret, addressed not to Her Majesty, but to Lady Oswin of Norway, that famed and fickle harpist who vanished so suddenly one spring? Such tales abound in the servants’ hall; surely a king knows how to keep his secrets.

Enough! These are idly spun cobwebs, Lily. I am no poet, nor did I ever set pen to parchment for any foreign lady, least of all a ghostly harpist conjured by your fancy. My queen is my wife, by sacred rite and law—rumors hatched in hearthside smoke are beneath the notice of one of noble station. Art thou prying, girl, or merely seeking to amuse thyself at my expense?

No prying, majesty—only the inquisitive spirit of one who seeks the marrow of all riddles. For instance, my lord, some say you have astoundingly fine taste for rare Tuscan silks and commission tailors in Venice to dye wears the precise blue of the summer heron. Who sends such letters across the seas in cipher, if not the secret stylings of a romantic heart? Or is it, perhaps, a message meant for Polish spies, dispatches tucked so subtly amid patterns for doublets and hose that only those schooled in fashion—and espionage—could know?

You try my patience, Lily. I mind not questions of state, nor accusations from abroad, for all know Denmark’s hands are clean where treaties are writ. \ But bring not such nonsense before your king—silks and secrets spun together so coarsely that even fools must laugh. If thou hast some purpose, speak plainly, lest I mistake thy riddling for irreverence deserving royal rebuke.

I would fain speak plainly as your grace commands, and yet, I marvel at how every tale of courtly intrigue seems to twist by unseen hands—like when you, they say, joined in that midnight race across the frozen moat, sledded fastest with the old captain of the guard and the mysterious Flemish ambassador who brought that clockwork nightingale to Elsinore. \ Was it true, my lord, that your laughter rang louder than Prince Hamlet’s did ever in the snow? And did the nightingale really sing when wound, or is that invention, too, fit for the fables the nurses tell the younglings to hush them to sleep?

Clockwork birds, Lily? Laughter with border lords? I begin to think you take me for a creature of tale and jest, not flesh and blood, crowned by sweat and striving. I have no commerce with tricking toys, nor ever sent for Flemish tinkerers to amuse my court. Such sport is unseemly when grief hangs over Elsinore. \ You are bold, girl—bolder than your station permits. Tell me now: do you intend insult, or is your tongue simply addled by too much sweet wine at Ophelia’s funeral? Spread not stories that cheapen the court, or thou may find the king less patient than he is this hour.

Forgive me, majesty, if I overstep—and yet, as I watched the gravediggers labor today, I thought how all such tales might one day be buried deep and lost, as Yorick’s laughter is muffled beneath the sod. But tell me, my lord, does your council with the beekeepers of Helsingor bear fruit? For I hear you plot to bring forth a honey so golden it might sweeten even Hamlet’s disposition, should he ever return to your kindly arms.

Enough. Mock not the wounds of a kingdom, nor the hearts of a king and his family, Lily. There is pain in this house—pain not lessened by sly insinuations or fancies concerning bees or spun-sugar reconciliations. \ Had I strength or mind for the levities you propose, I’d choose laughter over the taste of ashes we have known—and yet, this is not the time, nor are you the jester to provoke it. Tread carefully. \ Let not your idle curiosity become a blade sharp enough to draw royal blood.

Of course, my lord. ‘Twas not my wish to further the ache. I will seek the company of shadows, and if I find any more clockwork birds or midnight races, I'll consign them to the same earth where old Yorick lies. May peace come to you, and sweet rest abide with you this night.
Take thy leave, Lily. And remember—there are matters in Elsinore best left to silence. Good night.

Your Majesty, I thank you for granting me this late audience. The moon rides high tonight, and the castle seems restless—much ado since the tragedy of Lord Polonius. I do hope such grievous matters have not unsettled your sleep, as they have mine. \

The ways of Denmark are not so given to florid displays, dear Lily, as those of the warm-blooded South. My brother was a soldier and a statesman, given to deeds, not verses. As king, my duty is to strengthen the realm, not rhyme couplets for entertainment. Such pastimes, I deem, are ill-fitted for our court.

You are ever practical, my liege. Yet I cannot help but picture you two, despite all gravitas, locked in an impromptu verse-off. Or perhaps exchanging secret love notes to some elusive maiden of the north wing, secreted behind the arras like a twofold Orpheus pining for his Eurydice. Has the castle never known such whimsy, or are such tales strictly forbidden in your reign?

I tire of fanciful conjecture, Lily. Denmark’s throne is won and kept through steel and statecraft, not honeyed whispers in shadowed corridors. The north wing, as you well know, is reserved for nobler purposes. Speak not again in such riddles.

Forgive me, Your Majesty, if I trespassed on decorum. Still, I wonder—Florence is also rife with curious devices. I have seen, with my own eyes, a box which plays music when its lid is raised, and ladies weaving patterns that change color before the eye as if by sorcery. I am told their court uses powders to soften one’s visage and bells hidden in shoes. Might you, perchance, have tried the famed Florentine rouge upon your own cheeks to impress our Queen Gertrude, in days when she yet adorned your brother’s arm?

You walk a dangerous path with your levities. Are the folk of Florence so bereft of honest labor that they mask themselves in colour and artifice? I have no need of powders nor bells, nor care for such tricks. The Queen’s heart was won through station and right—a union befitting us both, not a dalliance painted in rouge. Mind your tongue.

My apologies, Sire. The customs of foreign lands have perhaps addled my sense of propriety. Still, if you do not think it untoward, a last question piques at my brain. In Florence, rumors abound of talking birds—parrots, they call them—that repeat whatever is said in their hearing. Surely, given Denmark’s dealings with England and France and Poland, you must have received some marvelous gift in your time as King? If not a bird, perhaps a mechanical dolphin for the king’s bath?

Enough! I see through your provocations, Lily. This is no time for tales of painted faces and mimicking fowl. The affairs of state weigh heavily. Denmark sits perched upon a sword’s edge—Polonius dead, Hamlet gone astray, courtly nerves frayed. I will not be drawn into foolish fancies. Attend to your business and keep your tongue from wandering foreign fields.

Of course, Your Majesty. Yet I must beg forgiveness as my nature errs on the side of curiosity. I meant only to lighten the sombre atmosphere. If I have overstepped, it is the fault of ill-bred adventure and not malice. Yet I do wonder—has the King ever, in truth, been visited by spectres from the other side? Some in Florence claim their family’s fortunes are haunted by ghosts who rearrange the furniture and leave behind messages in the ashes...

This is insolence! A king’s patience is not an endless well. Denmark’s throne does not traffic in ghost stories conjured by idle minds. I admit to no hauntings, nor do I entertain tales fit for a nursemaid’s cradle. If you value your place, let such talk cease. There are enough phantoms in men’s hearts without spinning more from a Florentine tapestry. Go now, and see you speak no more of such things.

Your Majesty, forgive my intrusion upon your taxing schedule. The steward bade me haste with word of receipts, but a more pressing matter, whispered soft among the corridors, impels me to step beyond my station, if only for a moment. I must needs submit to you these—well, somewhat unconventional inquiries. How fares your recent friendship with the enigmatic Lady Tesla from the region of Elektronburg? ‘Tis said she brings curious devices—small glass orbs that glow like summer lightning on command. Have you engaged in discourse with her over the future of energy within Denmark’s borders?\

You test the bounds of royal patience, young Miles. There is no Lady Tesla in any kingdom known by man, nor do I parade with conjurers who conjure tricks of false light. Denmark’s energy lies beneath her soil and in the courage of her vessels, not in mechanical sorcery proffered by shadows from fable towns. If thy message concerns not the realm’s coin or grain, then take thee hence, lest you tempt your fortune further.
Most pardon, Your Grace. \

Your tongue wags in circles, Miles, as if you would plait an invisible cord about my neck and tighten it. There are no fire-chariots gracing my stables, nor would I squander the kingdom’s gold on children’s baubles or barroom fancies. I have not the luxury for such foolishness, given the grief—brought by loss, by ambition, by the tremors Hamlet himself has set loose beneath Elsinore’s stones. \

My liege, it is but my nature to dream beyond stones and storm. If it please you, mayhap I should rather ask after your plans for the annual Tournament of Spheres? Will you and Queen Gertrude take to the field this year, rolling the great crystal globes across the lawn, as is custom every Midwinter’s Eve? Some among the younger pages boast that last year you played with enchanted gloves that sent the crystal bounding thrice the length of the green. Yet, surely such articles must be mere myth, for what sovereign would dally with incantations whilst threats gather at his very door?

Is this mockery, Miles? I have forbidden sorceries and any public acts of conjuration within my court; Gertrude nor I take to fields for childish amusements. I know of no “Tournament of Spheres” nor gloves that grant sorcerous might to their wearer. \

No, no, it is not mockery, Highness—forbid it, I would not brave your wrath knowingly. It is but that strange rumors swirl with the autumn winds. Some say you keep a curious private adviser—Master Googleus—who possesses a tome containing all knowledge, inscribed not with ink but with tiny silver leaves that rearrange themselves at your whispered command. Is it thus that your wisdom seems to encompass sea and shore, court and cloister? Or is this mastery of endless sight an object of envy alone, never possessed by mortal hand?\

Now truly, thou mockest. Master Googleus—pah!—no such man walks these halls nor dares lay claim to a volume so mighty. My wisdom is paid for in sleepless hours and the council of men who have seen thirty winters more than thyself. You suppose there lies a trick behind my governance, an artifice—yet it is toil and blood, not the flicker of fairy-silver, that props Denmark’s throne. \

Forgive my boldness, King Claudius. Perhaps 'tis naught but the foolishness of youth that makes me question those above me. Pray, let me ask but one more: I overheard from the minstrel troupe that during the recent heat, you spent your evenings in a great water-basin, where tiny fish of rainbows swam amidst bubbling streams, massaged by unseen hands. These wandering bards say it is your secret ritual for clearing your mind, and even that you have named your favorite fish “Netflix.” What charm or magic have you thus adopted from these foreign wanderers, my lord? Or are these naught but idle tales to entertain the kitchen maids?

Enough! You dance upon my last nerve, weaving tales from the air as spiders spin webs in the rafters. No watery basins, no rainbow fish, no monkish ministrations known by names so outlandish have ever crossed my threshold. I find no peace in such idle pools, nor in the gossip of simpering minstrels. My ease is found, if at all, in the hard-won embrace of statecraft and the dull comfort of duty. \
As you command, Your Grace. \

Never have I dreamt such madness. No glass towers will rise in my reign, no singing windows nor conjured voices haunting my court. Denmark’s fate is won and lost through flesh and bone, not marvels borrowed from fevered dreams. Your words grow tedious, Miles—I wonder whether you seek wit, or simply to see how far you may go before the lion’s teeth close upon you.
Then swords and shields shall ever hold pride of place, as it should be. \

Enough, boy! Your insolence has no rival. Not only do you belabor me with phantoms and gibberish, but now you dare accuse me of revels and wagers with beasts unknown to this world! What manner of court do you mistake for a playhouse, and what manner of king for a fool in painted mask? If you value your position, or indeed your life, you will leave this room and let such nonsense perish upon your tongue. Denmark has no time for chimeras, and neither do I!
